Why Linen Tops Are a Must-Have for Ladies in Sri Lanka’s Tropical Weather?
Linen tops have become an essential wardrobe staple for women in Sri Lanka, thanks to
their lightweight and breathable nature. Given Sri Lanka’s tropical climate, which is
characterized by high humidity and warm temperatures, linen is one of the best fabric
choices for staying cool and stylish. This article explores the many reasons why linen
tops for ladies in Sri Lanka are a must-have, highlighting their benefits, styling tips,
and why they stand out as the perfect blend of comfort and elegance. Linen is a natural
fiber derived from the flax plant, making it incredibly breathable. It allows air to
circulate around the body, helping to wick away moisture and keep you feeling fresh
throughout the day. In a hot and humid country like Sri Lanka, this is crucial for
maintaining comfort, whether you’re at work, running errands, or attending a casual
gathering. One of the best properties of linen is its ability to absorb moisture while
drying quickly. This makes linen tops ideal for daily wear in Sri Lanka’s humid
conditions, as they help to prevent excessive sweating and discomfort. Linen tops are
lightweight, making them a preferred choice for everyday fashion. They don’t cling to the
body, allowing for better airflow. Unlike synthetic fabrics, which can feel suffocating,
linen provides a natural and relaxed feel. Linen tops come in a variety of styles, from
casual button-down shirts to elegant blouses and trendy tunics. Whether you prefer a
relaxed fit or a more structured look, there are plenty of options available to suit
different fashion preferences. Despite being lightweight, linen tops can be layered
effortlessly. Pair a linen blouse with a camisole underneath for a chic, layered look. For
cooler days or air-conditioned environments, throwing on a lightweight scarf or a cotton
cardigan can complement the outfit beautifully. Sustainability is an important factor when
choosing clothing, and linen is one of the most environmentally friendly fabrics
available. Linen production requires less water and fewer chemicals compared to cotton,
making it a great choice for eco-conscious consumers. Although linen is known for its
tendency to wrinkle, this adds to its charm, giving it a relaxed, effortless look.
Moreover, linen tops are easy to care for; they can be hand-washed or machine-washed and
typically become softer with each wash. For Sri Lankan women looking to combine comfort
with style, linen tops are an excellent choice. Their breathability, moisture-wicking
properties, and versatile designs make them a must-have in any wardrobe. Whether you’re
heading to the office, going out for lunch, or simply relaxing at home, linen tops ensure
that you stay cool and stylish all day long. Discover a beautiful collection of stylish
and high-quality linen tops for ladies in Sri Lanka at Akira.lk . Elevate your wardrobe
with breathable, elegant, and eco-friendly fashion today!

Fashion Tips for Dressing Confidently in the Tropical Climate
Living in a tropical country like Sri Lanka means sunshine, humidity, and occasional rain
— all of which affect our fashion choices. Here’s how to stay stylish without compromising
comfort in this weather. Go for cotton, linen, or rayon instead of synthetic fabrics.
These materials let your skin breathe and keep sweat at bay. They also drape beautifully
and feel soft against your skin. Dark colors absorb heat, while light shades reflect it.
Whites, pas Avoid tight fits that cling to the body. Flowy dresses, relaxed shirts, and
airy frocks keep you cool and offer freedom of movement — all while giving you that laid-
back tropical vibe. If you must layer (e.g., for work or temple visits), pick lightweight
outerwear like chiffon shrugs or breathable cotton jackets. Always have an umbrella or
scarf ready for unpredictable rain. Tropical heat and heavy accessories don’t mix. Choose
light jewelry, natural makeup, and breathable footwear like sandals or slides to feel good
all day. Style is

The Bold Return of Batik Shirts in Sri Lanka
Batik shirts in Colombo have seen a powerful revival in recent years. Once seen primarily
at cultural events or on souvenir stalls, these beautifully hand-dyed garments are now a
statement piece in modern Sri Lankan wardrobes. The charm of the batik shirt lies in its
story — each pattern and hue is crafted using a traditional wax-resist dyeing process,
giving it depth and uniqueness. Unlike mass-produced fashion, batik is slow and soulful.
Whether it’s bold abstract designs, natural motifs, or symmetrical patterns, a batik shirt
offers a canvas of heritage wrapped in wearable art. What makes batik shirts so appealing
today is their versatility. They seamlessly blend the old with the new. You can wear a
light batik shirt with jeans for a casual look, or dress it up with tailored trousers and
loafers for a semi-formal event. In Colombo’s growing urban fashion scene, you’ll find
both men and women confidently styling batik shirts at cafes, co-working spaces, and even
at weddings. The shift isn’t just aesthetic—it’s cultural. People are proudly embracing
locally made products that speak to their identity and creativity. Batik isn’t just
fashion—it’s a movement that respects heritage while staying stylish. There’s also an
environmental and ethical appeal to batik fashion . Since each piece is handmade, it
encourages sustainable production and supports local artisans. Choosing batik shirts in
Sri Lanka means supporting a system that values craftsmanship over fast fashion. Many
young designers are now collaborating with batik artisans to create modern silhouettes,
gender-neutral styles, and inclusive fits. This evolution has helped batik move from
traditional to trendy, without losing its cultural roots. To find the perfect batik shirts
in Colombo , head to Akira.lk . Their collection merges traditional designs with modern
cuts, offering something for every taste. Whether you’re looking for something bold or
minimal, Akira ensures you wear your culture proudly and fashionably.

White Dresses – The Timeless Trend in Sri Lankan Fashion
There’s a quiet elegance to a white dress , and in Sri Lanka, this minimal classic has
never really gone out of style. From school uniforms to bridal wear, the color white has
long been associated with purity, simplicity, and serenity. But in the modern fashion
scene, white dresses in Sri Lanka have taken on a whole new life. They are now being worn
as everyday wear, party outfits , and formal attire thanks to their ability to look
effortlessly chic. Light, breathable fabrics like cotton and linen make white dresses
ideal for Sri Lanka’s tropical climate, offering comfort without compromising on
sophistication. The beauty of white frocks in Sri Lanka lies in their adaptability. A
single white dress can be styled in countless ways — with bold accessories for a party
look, with sneakers and a denim jacket for a casual vibe, or with heels and pearls for
something more refined. Whether it’s a lace-trimmed midi dress for brunch or a floor-
length cotton gown for an outdoor function, white dresses never fail to make a statement.
The trend is especially popular during Avurudu, graduation ceremonies, and beach weddings,
where the color complements both the occasion and the scenery. What’s also appealing is
that white dresses in Sri Lanka work across ages and body types. They create a clean
canvas that enhances natural beauty and provides a base for creative styling. Plus, white
tones reflect heat, making them not just fashionable but also practical for sunny island
life. Many local designers are now focusing on white frocks with delicate embroidery,
ruffled sleeves, or even batik details—offering a perfect blend of tradition and trend.

The Comeback of Linen: From Ancient Threads to Modern Trends
Linen is one of the oldest known fabrics, dating back to ancient Egypt where it was worn
by royalty and revered for its purity and comfort. Over centuries, this timeless textile
faded in popularity, replaced by synthetics and heavy blends. But now, linen is making a
remarkable comeback—especially in warm, tropical countries like Sri Lanka. Linen is made
from the flax plant and has been used for over 6,000 years. Ancient civilizations valued
it for being light, durable, and breathable—ideal for hot climates. It was even used to
wrap Egyptian mummies, symbolizing purity and elegance. Sri Lanka’s tropical heat demands
smart fashion choices. Linen’s natural fibers allow air to flow, keeping the body cool and
dry. Plus, it absorbs moisture quickly and dries faster than cotton. With today’s modern
tailoring, linen no longer means “crumpled”—it means effortlessly stylish . At Akira.lk,
linen has evolved. From chic linen dresses to smart-casual shirts and office-ready
outfits, you’ll find pieces that honor the fabric’s roots while embracing fresh,
contemporary designs. It’s sustainable, breathable, and undeniably fashionable. Linen
isn’t just a trend — it’s a return to elegance, simplicity, and comfort. Add a few linen
staples to your wardrobe and feel the difference every time you step outside. Shop

The Rise of Handloom Linen in Sustainable Fashion
In recent years, sustainability has become a driving force in the fashion industry, and
handloom linen is at the forefront of this movement. Known for its breathability,
durability, and eco-friendly qualities, linen is rapidly gaining popularity among fashion
enthusiasts. Linen dresses and linen frocks are becoming essential wardrobe staples for
those who value both style and sustainability. One of the key reasons for the rise of
handloom linen is its minimal environmental impact. Linen is made from flax, a plant that
requires significantly less water and fewer pesticides than cotton. This makes linen
frocks and linen dresses a more sustainable choice for eco-conscious consumers.
Additionally, linen’s natural fibers are biodegradable, further reducing its environmental
footprint. In Sri Lanka, designers are increasingly blending batik wear with linen to
create unique, sustainable pieces. For instance, a batik silk dress with linen accents
combines the artistry of traditional batik with the comfort and sustainability of linen.
This fusion not only preserves cultural heritage but also promotes responsible fashion
practices. The versatility of linen makes it suitable for various occasions. A simple
linen dress can be styled for a casual day out, while an elegant linen frock can be
dressed up for more formal events. Pairing linen with batik designer dresses or batik silk
sarees creates a harmonious blend of tradition and modernity. For special occasions,
consider wearing a batik wedding saree made with linen elements, combining luxury with
sustainability. The demand for sri lanka batik dresses and linen products reflects a

Saree Stories: Exploring Different Draping Styles Across Sri Lanka
The saree is more than just a garment in Sri Lanka; it’s a symbol of tradition, elegance,
and cultural pride. With each region offering its unique draping style, the saree can be
transformed to reflect various histories, lifestyles, and social nuances. Here’s a look at
some of Sri Lanka’s diverse draping styles that showcase the beauty and versatility of
this timeless attire. The Kandyan style, or Osariya, is one of the most well-known and
widely worn styles in Sri Lanka, especially among Sinhalese women. It involves wrapping
the saree with pleats at the side, and the fall is tucked at the back, creating a fishtail
effect. A separate jacket and frill add elegance to this style, making it perfect for
weddings, celebrations, and formal occasions. The Osariya reflects the grace and poise of
Kandyan culture, adding a regal charm to the wearer. While not native to Sri Lanka, the
Indian Nivi drape has gained popularity due to its simplicity and adaptability. In this
style, pleats are made in the front, and the pallu (the decorative end of the saree) is
draped over the shoulder. This versatile style is ideal for both everyday wear and formal
events, allowing easy movement and a flattering silhouette. Predominantly worn by Tamil
women, the Madisar drape is traditional in Tamil weddings and ceremonies. This style
involves wrapping the saree in a way that resembles a pair of trousers, symbolizing
strength and commitment in marriage. The Madisar’s unique drape requires a longer saree
and a special technique, making it a true celebration of Tamil heritage. In modern Sri
Lankan fashion , fusion drapes are increasingly popular, blending traditional elements
with contemporary styles. Experimenting with belted pallu, asymmetrical drapes, or pairing
the saree with unconventional blouses, the contemporary style allows individuals to
express their creativity while honoring tradition. Each saree drape in Sri Lanka

Linen vs. Cotton: Which Fabric is Right for You?
Choosing between linen and cotton can be a tough decision, as both fabrics offer unique
benefits suited to various styles and climates. Here’s a quick comparison to help you
decide which fabric suits your lifestyle, comfort, and wardrobe needs best. Both linen and
cotton are known for their breathability, making them ideal for warm weather. However,
linen, made from the flax plant, is particularly well-suited for tropical climates as it
naturally wicks away moisture and dries quickly. Cotton, being softer and more versatile,
provides everyday comfort and is gentle on sensitive skin. Best Choice: For hot, humid
weather or beachwear, linen’s cooling properties make it ideal. For all-day comfort,
cotton’s softness is hard to beat. Linen is one of the strongest natural fibers, and its
durability only improves with washing. It’s designed to last through years of wear without
losing its texture . Cotton is also durable but less resistant to wear over time,
especially if it’s lightweight or untreated. Best Choice: If you’re looking for longevity,
especially in staple pieces, linen is a fantastic choice for its resilience. Linen is
known for its slightly textured, rustic look and often sports a natural wrinkle, which
adds character to any outfit . Cotton, in contrast, can look crisper and is available in
various finishes, from polished and formal to casual and cozy. Best Choice: If you prefer
a refined, relaxed look, linen is ideal for casual and semi-formal wear . For versatility
and polish, cotton fits almost any style. Linen is easy to care for and often looks best
with minimal ironing. Cotton, while easy to maintain, may require a bit more attention to
keep looking pristine, especially if used for formal wear . Discover the best in linen and
cotton at Akira, where you’ll find high-quality, stylish options to suit your every need!

The Cultural Significance of White Dresses in Sri Lankan Ceremonies
White clothing holds deep symbolic meaning in Sri Lankan culture. From religious rituals
to school functions and weddings, white garments signify purity, peace, humility, and
respect. These values are deeply rooted in both Buddhist and Hindu traditions practiced
across the island. In Buddhist culture, white is commonly worn during visits to temples or
religious observances such as Poya days. It reflects a person’s inner clarity and
sincerity in devotion. Wearing white to such events is not just a custom; it’s a quiet
gesture of spiritual reverence. Similarly, in Hindu religious ceremonies, white is often
used to denote sanctity and spiritual readiness. White dresses are also a key element in
school uniforms in Sri Lanka, particularly for girls. The dress symbolizes equality and
discipline, values held dear in the educational system. In marriage ceremonies, white
dresses or sarees are chosen to represent the purity and auspiciousness of the bride’s new
beginning. Modern white dresses come in many styles today, often blending tradition with
subtle lace, embroidery, or flowy silhouettes. They are not only ceremonial but also a
symbol of timeless elegance. For those wanting to honor Sri Lankan culture with elegant,
traditional white dresses , Akira.lk offers a beautiful selection that respects heritage
while providing modern comfort and style. Explore their range and find the perfect dress
for your next special occasion.

Styling Silk Batik Sarees for Modern Occasions
Silk batik sarees are a timeless symbol of elegance and tradition, now reimagined for the
modern woman. With their luxurious texture and intricate hand-drawn patterns, silk batik
sarees in Sri Lanka have become a popular choice for everything from weddings to formal
dinners and cultural events. These sarees offer a beautiful blend of traditional artistry
and contemporary fashion, making them ideal for women who want to celebrate heritage while
embracing a modern look. When styling a silk batik saree for a wedding or reception, rich
tones like maroon, emerald, or royal blue work beautifully. Pair your saree with a
sleeveless, off-shoulder, or high-neck blouse to create a stylish silhouette that flatters
the figure. Accessorize with bold statement earrings, a sleek updo, and a clutch to
complete the elegant ensemble. For formal dinners or office parties, go for more muted
silk batik sarees in soft pas For cultural or religious occasions, choose traditional
batik sarees in earthy colors or vibrant hues that reflect Sri Lankan heritage. A modest
blouse and classic draping style preserve the cultural aesthetic while still looking
graceful. Meanwhile, for fashion-forward events or photoshoots, don’t be afraid to
experiment. Try an asymmetrical drape or wear the saree with a modern crop top or a
tailored jacket. Metallic or chunky accessories can further elevate the look. Modernizing
your silk batik saree can be as simple as trying a unique blouse design, belting the saree

White Dresses in Sri Lankan Culture: When and How to Wear Them
White has long been a symbol of purity, peace, and elegance in Sri Lankan culture. From
religious ceremonies to formal occasions, a white dress holds deep cultural significance
and is a timeless fashion choice. Whether you’re attending a temple ceremony, a wedding,
or a casual event, knowing when and how to wear white can enhance your style while
respecting tradition. In Sri Lanka, white clothing is often associated with Buddhist and
Hindu religious ceremonies. Devotees commonly wear white dresses or sarees when visiting
temples or participating in religious observances. White represents purity and
mindfulness, making it the preferred color for spiritual gatherings. Additionally, many
traditional Sri Lankan weddings incorporate white attire. Brides often wear white sarees
with intricate embroidery, symbolizing new beginnings and blessings. In Tamil culture,
white is also worn during specific rituals, adding a layer of cultural richness to this
timeless color. A simple white dress or a white cotton saree is ideal for temple visits.
It reflects respect and devotion while keeping you comfortable in Sri Lanka’s warm
climate. Many women opt for linen white dresses , as they offer both elegance and
breathability. While brides traditionally wear white, guests can also wear elegant white
dresses with subtle designs to daytime weddings or formal receptions. If you’re attending
a Western-style wedding in Sri Lanka, a chic white midi dress or a flowy maxi dress can be
a great choice. White dresses aren’t just for special occasions. A casual white linen
dress or a cotton white frock is perfect for brunch outings, beach strolls, or relaxed
weekends. The neutral tone allows for endless styling possibilities, whether paired with
sandals for a laid-back look or heels for an evening out. A white shirt dress or a white
midi dress with structured tailoring can be an elegant yet professional choice for office

patterns and colors. The uniqueness of hand-dyed fabrics like Batik lies in the meticulous
craftsmanship that goes into every piece. Each design What sets Batik apart from other
fabrics is its labor-intensive process. Artisans use wax to outline their designs before
dipping the fabric into dyes. Multiple layers of waxing and dyeing create vibrant,
intricate patterns. No two pieces of Batik are exactly alike, making each item you wear a
statement of individuality. The wax-resist technique ensures that colors blend seamlessly,
giving Batik its characteristic charm and depth. Batik is also versatile. Whether worn as
a sarong , shirt , or dress , it exudes elegance and cultural pride. The richness of Batik
patterns and the skill of the artisans make this fabric ideal for any occasion, from

The Evolution of Batik Patterns Through Time
Batik, a traditional fabric art form renowned for its intricate patterns and vibrant
colors, has evolved significantly over the centuries. From its ancient origins to
contemporary fashion, batik patterns have undergone a remarkable transformation,
reflecting changes in cultural, social, and artistic trends. Here’s a journey through the
evolution of batik patterns and how they continue to shape and influence modern design.
Batik’s origins can be traced back to ancient Indonesia, where it was initially used for
ceremonial and ritualistic purposes. The earliest batik patterns were deeply symbolic,
often depicting motifs related to nature, spirituality, and social status. Designs such as
floral patterns, geometric shapes, and s ymbolic imagery were created using traditional
resist-dye techniques, which involved applying hot wax to fabric to create intricate
designs. During the Javanese period, batik patterns became more sophisticated and refined.
The art form was highly developed in Java, with distinct regional styles emerging. For
instance, the “Parang” motif symbolized strength and was reserved for royalty, while
“Kawung” patterns, inspired by the shape of palm flowers, were used for everyday wear.
These classic motifs became iconic representations of Javanese culture and batik
craftsmanship . The arrival of European colonizers in Southeast Asia introduced new
influences to batik design . Colonial-era batik often combined traditional Indonesian
patterns with European artistic elements, leading to a fusion of styles. This period saw
the introduction of new colors, patterns, and techniques, resulting in unique hybrid
designs that reflected the cross-cultural exchanges of the time. As batik moved into the
20th century, it began to adapt to changing fashion trends and technological advancements.
Modern batik artists and designers started experimenting with new materials, dyes, and
techniques, leading to a broader range of patterns and styles. Contemporary batik patterns
often incorporate abstract designs, geometric shapes, and bold color combinations,
reflecting the influence of modern art and design movements. With the globalization of
fashion, batik has found its way onto international runways and into global fashion
markets. Designers from around the world have embraced batik’s unique aesthetic,
integrating it into high fashion collections and everyday wear. This global exposure has
led to the evolution of batik patterns, blending traditional motifs with contemporary
influences to create fresh, innovative designs. In the digital age, batik has continued to
evolve with the advent of new technologies. Digital printing and advanced textile
techniques have allowed for greater precision and creativity in batik design. Artists and
designers can now experiment with intricate patterns, vibrant colors, and unconventional
materials , pushing the boundaries of traditional batik and expanding its possibilities.
Looking forward, the future of batik patterns lies in balancing the preservation of
traditional techniques with the embrace of modern innovation. As designers continue to
explore new possibilities and interpretations, batik remains a dynamic and evolving art
form. The ongoing evolution of batik patterns ensures that this rich cultural heritage
continues to inspire and captivate new generations. Batik’s journey from ancient craft to
contemporary fashion is a testament to its enduring appeal and adaptability. By exploring
the evolution of batik patterns , we gain a deeper appreciation for this timeless art form
and its impact on global fashion.

Handloom Fabrics: The Ultimate Guide to Care and Maintenance
Handloom fabrics are cherished for their craftsmanship, beauty, and cultural significance.
To ensure their longevity and maintain their stunning appearance, it’s essential to care
for them properly. Whether you’re new to handloom textiles or looking to refine your care
routine, this guide provides you with everything you need to keep your handloom pieces in
pristine condition. Handloom fabrics are delicate and should be washed with care. Always
opt for hand washing using cold water and a mild detergent. Avoid wringing or twisting the
fabric; instead, gently press out excess water and lay it flat to dry. If machine washing
is necessary, use a gentle cycle and place the fabric in a mesh laundry bag . Store
handloom fabrics in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight to prevent fading. It’s
best to fold them neatly and place them in a cotton or muslin bag to protect against dust
and insects. For heavier fabrics like handloom silk, avoid hanging them for long periods
as this can cause stretching. Ironing handloom fabrics requires attention to detail.
Always use a low-heat setting and iron on the reverse side to protect the fabric’s
surface. For added protection, place a thin cotton cloth between the iron and the fabric.
If you’re unsure, steaming is a safer alternative for removing wrinkles. In the event of a
stain, act quickly. Blot the area with a clean, damp cloth—never rub, as this can spread
the stain. For tougher stains, a mixture of water and white vinegar can be effective, but
always test on a small, inconspicuous area first. To keep your handloom fabrics fresh,
it’s a good idea to air them out occasionally. Simply hang them in a shaded area with good
airflow to prevent any mustiness from developing over time. By following these simple care
and maintenance tips, you can ensure that your handloom pieces remain as beautiful and
vibrant as the day you bought them. At Akira, we are passionate

Embrace the Heritage of Batik with Akira : The History and Cultural Significance of Batik
Immerse yourself in the vibrant world of batik, a captivating textile art form known for
its intricate patterns and rich colors. This extraordinary craft, which weaves together
centuries of cultural heritage and artistic brilliance, is a living testament to the
creativity and traditions of diverse cultures. The term “batik” is derived from the
Javanese word “tik,” which means to dot or to make dots. While the exact origins of batik
are difficult to ascertain, it is widely accepted that the batik-making techniques were
first refined in Indonesia, particularly on the island of Java. Historical records suggest
that batik was being crafted as early as the 4th century BC. The creation of batik is a
meticulous and labor-intensive process involving the application of wax-resistant dye to
fabric. The traditional method, known as “batik tulis,” entails drawing intricate designs
with a canting, a small tool that dispenses hot wax. This wax serves as a resist,
preventing the dye from penetrating certain areas of the fabric. The process is repeated
multiple times with different colors to produce complex, multi-layered designs. Batik
holds immense cultural significance in many countries, particularly in Indonesia,
Malaysia, Sri Lanka, and parts of Africa. Each region boasts unique styles, motifs, and
symbolic meanings associated with batik patterns. In Indonesia, batik transcends mere
fabric, embodying cultural identity and national pride. In 2009, UNESCO recognized
Indonesian batik as a Masterpiece of Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity. Traditional
Javanese batik patterns often carry symbolic meanings, with specific designs reserved for
royalty and special occasions. For instance, the “Parang” motif symbolizes strength and
resilience, while the “Kawung” pattern represents wisdom and justice. In Africa, batik has
a storied history and is an integral part of traditional attire in several countries,
including Nigeria, Ghana, and Senegal. African batik is renowned for its bold and vibrant
designs, often featuring symbolic and spiritual motifs. The fabrics are utilized for
various purposes, including clothing, ceremonial garments, and home decor. Introduced
during the Dutch colonial era, Sri Lankan batik has developed its unique style, merging
traditional and contemporary elements. Known for its bold and vibrant designs, Sri Lankan
batik often depicts scenes from nature and religious motifs. The town of Matale is
particularly renowned for its batik artisans, who continue to innovate while preserving
the traditional techniques. In Sri Lanka, batik is more than just a fabric; it’s an
embodiment of the island’s rich cultural heritage. The meticulous craftsmanship and
vibrant colors of Sri Lankan batik reflect the country’s artistic traditions and natural
beauty. Each piece Modern Influence and Global Appeal Batik has transcended its
traditional roots, garnering popularity and recognition on the global stage. Contemporary
fashion designers and artists have embraced batik, incorporating its patterns and
techniques into modern clothing, accessories, and art. This fusion of traditional and
modern elements has helped preserve and promote batik as a living art form. Embrace the
Heritage of Batik with Akira The history and cultural significance of batik are a
testament to its timeless beauty and relevance. From its ancient origins to its global
influence today, batik continues to captivate and inspire. By supporting and wearing
batik, we celebrate a remarkable art form and contribute to preserving the cultural

Here’s why Handloom Textiles are the ultimate choice for eco-friendly fashion
In the realm of fashion, sustainability is no longer a mere trend but a vital commitment.
Handloom textiles stand out as a beacon of eco-friendly fashion, offering a greener
alternative to conventional manufacturing methods. At Akira, we proudly embrace the
sustainability of handloom fabrics, and here’s why they are a standout choice for the eco-
conscious consumer: Handloom textiles are crafted using traditional methods that
significantly reduce environmental impact. Unlike industrial fabric production, which
relies heavily on machinery and chemical dyes, handloom weaving utilizes minimal energy
and predominantly natural dyes. This process not only conserves resources but also ensures
that each piece is crafted with care and respect for the environment. Choosing handloom
fabrics means supporting skilled artisans and preserving age-old techniques. Each
handwoven garment Handloom textiles often use natural fibers such as cotton, silk, and
wool, which are biodegradable and have a lower environmental footprint compared to
synthetic alternatives. These materials decompose naturally, reducing waste and promoting
a more sustainable lifecycle for your clothing. Industrial textile production is notorious
for its excessive water usage. Handloom weaving, on the other hand, is far more water-
efficient. The dyeing process in handloom textiles typically uses less water, and many
artisans employ natural dyes that are less harmful to aquatic ecosystems. Handloom fabrics
are renowned for their exceptional quality and durability. Investing in high-quality,
timeless pieces means you are less likely to engage in fast fashion cycles. Instead, you
enjoy long-lasting garments that stand the test of time, both in style and sustainability.
Many handloom producers follow fair trade practices, ensuring that artisans are paid
fairly and work in safe conditions. By supporting handloom textiles, you align with
ethical fashion principles that prioritize fair labor practices and social responsibility.

they are sustainable. Explore our curated selection of handloom garments and join us in

Affordable Clothing Brands in Sri Lanka
Mar 27 2025. Today we are showing some love to a few of our very own local clothing
brands. Here are my top 4 great, yet lesser-known clothing brands in Sri Lanka that I came
across over the past couple of years. These emerging brands aren’t just making clothes;
they ‘re telling stories and empowering themselves and our communities. Every piece you
choose from one of these brands is more than just an outfit. It’s a piece of Sri Lanka,
crafted with love and care. If you’re looking to refresh your wardrobe with some chic and
cute pieces without breaking the bank, Flamingo SL is the place to be! I have shopped at
Flamingo SL many times and they never disappoint. This Sri Lankan brand offers a fantastic
selection of trendy clothes that are perfect for any occasion. What makes Flamingo SL even
more special is their commitment to supporting local design and businesses. They opened
their first store last year and it is a testament to this commitment as there are many
other local brands at the store. So while you shop for clothes at Flamingo SL you can also
shop for accessories under one roof. Their tops start from LKR 2000, dresses and trousers
from LKR 4000, and skirts from LKR 2500. Check out their full range of clothes in-store or
online. I absolutely love Absolute Basics! Let me tell you why I love this Sri Lankan
clothing brand. Sometimes all I want is to wear really comfortable clothes and look nice
in them. I always pick my absolute basics tops and pants to do the job. They are made of
high-quality, lightweight, and breathable fabrics and I absolutely love them. AB clothes
are perfect for Sri Lanka’s tropical climate because it keeps you cool and comfortable all
day long. They offer comfortable and stylish pieces that are perfect for both casual
outings and formal office settings. Another big plus is that the prices are very
reasonable for the quality you’re getting. Tops and t-shirts start from LKR 2500, dresses
from LKR 5500, pants from LKR 4500 and there’s so much more to choose from. They have
sales from time to time and prices drop even more. Of course, don’t take my word for it…
the best way to know if you’ll love it is to try it out for yourself. Their flagship store
is down Galle Road in Colpetty and they also have a store in One Galle Face Mall. You can
always check out their online store too. I found Maia two years ago when I stumbled upon
their Christmas collection. It was so beautiful and elegant but had sold out by the time I

became a favourite of mine for several reasons. Maia clothes have that classic look that
never goes out of style, but they also have a modern twist that makes them feel elegant
and current. Maia prices are so reasonable, so it’s easy to justify investing in pieces
that I’ll love for years to come. Their dresses are priced from LKR 5000 upwards. Maia is
definitely worth checking out. It’s a brand that truly embodies the spirit of Sri Lankan
fashion. These are just a few examples of the incredible talent thriving in Sri Lanka's
fashion scene, there are so many more. So this is an invitation to find local brands, buy
pieces that resonate with you, and create your own unique style. Happy shopping! By

From Heritage to Streetwear: Common Folk weaving a modern tale of innovation
Feb 16 2024. Handloom textile weaving in Sri Lanka is said to date back to the 6th century
BC as early as when Prince Vijaya from India landed in Sri Lanka and first saw Kuveni, a
queen of an indigenous race of Yakshas (demon tribe) spinning yarn at the wheel. Fast
forward to the 21st century, the traditional art and craft is still alive, surviving
industrialization, a brutal civil war and even the recent crisis. Teaming up and pursuing
the art with innovation, is a lawyer and a designer Sharendra Peiris and Thamali
Dharmawardena, co-founders of the handloom textile R&D and innovation brand “Common Folk”.
Since its inception in 2017, their main focus (motto) has been directed towards “uplifting
heritage crafts with technology.” They are the creators behind unique sneakers designed
with handloom. The art of handloom weaving involves the creation of textiles by
interlacing threads primarily made out of cotton (coloured with natural dyes), on a loom
operated manually. Pictured: Thamali Dharmawarden After almost 5 years of research, Common
Folk creates a breakthrough in the industry by discovering a production feasible method
that adds waterproofing functionality and abrasive level durability to traditional
handloom textiles. Sitting with Daily Mirror Life, Dharmawardena gives us an insight into
their story and the evolution of their work. “Common Folk is a homage to all the brilliant
people we have met and collecte dalong the way in the past 7-8 years. Firstly, Sharendra
and I consider ourselves common folk. Throughout the years, we have learned and grown with
the help of our talented artisans, tutors, technology partners, manufacturers, family,
friends, and colleagues. No matter our differences, our passion for our respective crafts
bind us. That passion and commitment make us all Common Folk." Pictured: Sharendra Peiris
Q TELL US THE STORY OF HOW YOU GOT INTO HANDLOOM WEAVING? WHAT WAS THE INSPIRATION BEHIND
PURSUING THIS TRADITIONAL CRAFT? Being very new to handloom weaving, it is actually less
than ten years since we began pursuing it. The first exposure to the craft was during my
second year in my BA programme. Our college took us to experience many different
traditional crafts. But something about creating a textile from scratch and watching the
weaving process in a handloom intrigued me the most. Being an analytical thinker, I then
dove into researching handloom textiles and the handloom market. During this research, it
became apparent to me that the Sri Lankan handloom market was on a decline. So our goal
became to sustain and uplift it. We started out by wanting to make something new and
unique that would open the handloom craft to much bigger opportunities. After years of R&D
(almost 5 years), we finally found a method to add the waterproof functionality to
handloom textiles. This was a breakthrough moment for us. But adding to our joy, we found
out that our waterproof handloom textiles were very durable, making it feasible to be used
in highly abrasive products. Being two people who love streetwear, Sharendra and I
immediately went for sneakers! Q CAN YOU WALK ME THROUGH THE PROCESS OF DESIGNING A PAIR
OF SNEAKERS USING HANDLOOM TEXTILE? Initially, we start by selecting yarns and thread
compatible with our waterproofing technology. We also select them in the colours and
thicknesses we need. Our weavers then do their magic to warp the loom into our chosen
design and begin weaving. One thing we didn’t want to compromise on was the natural
sustainability and social sustainability factors of weaving handlooms. So once the designs
are masterfully woven, we clean up the fabric and send it to be waterproofed by our
locally based technology partners.This makes them extra durable too. Once done, we send
them to our shoe manufacturing partners (locally based) to turn our fabric into sneakers.
The entire process takes around 3-4 months. These shoes were the first product we launched
for the retail market. We have fondly named them after some cities and places we hold
dear. Are there any traditional techniques or tools that you incorporate into your weaving
process? Are there any particular designs or patterns that you specialize in? One of our
primary design innovations is the Ombre handloom, where the colours in the fabric areindistinguishable from one another, showing a smooth gradient effect. This technique is
far smoother in transition than any other we have seen in the market. Q YOU SURELY MIGHT
HAVE HAD/HAVE SOME CHALLENGES OR DIFFICULTIES YOU HAVE TO OVERCOME PURSUING TRADITIONAL
HANDLOOM? Yes definitely. We were relatively new to the handloom industry; we did not come
from a family of handloom weavers or have ever experienced anything about handloom before.
So our journey was not quick, short, or easy. But our purpose kept us going and helped us
jump through all the obstacles we encountered. One other thing is our process in handloom
right now is labour-intensive and very lengthy. We are combining three different
industries and markets to create one product, and the most challenging part is
coordinating with each of them to work smoothly. As we both have our day jobs, finding the
time is a big challenge. Everything else in creating the product, missteps and side steps
etc. we encounter are all part of the experience, and we don’t consider them to be
difficulties or challenges. They are more of a motivator for us. Q ASIDE HANDLOOM WOVEN
SNEAKERS, WHAT ARE OTHER PRODUCTS DO YOU WORK WITH? Our main innovation is waterproof
handloom fabrics. With this, we have created a few exciting products, like waterproof bags
and cushion covers. We are now experimenting with handloom umbrellas. We also currently
have 6 different fabric designs in two colourways, but we hope to expand this very soon. Q
COULD YOU SHARE WITH US ANY MEMORABLE EXPERIENCES OR STORIES WHEN BOTH OF YOU BEGAN
PURSUING THIS CRAFT? I would say that all of our interactions with our artisans have been
and are very special to us. We work with one family and we have created an amazing bond
with them. We primarily collaborate with handloom weavers in Madampella. Latha and Bandula
are 2 such handloom artisans who throughout the years, have been our teachers, guides, and
sources of inspiration for Common Folk. Our fondest memory with them falls during the
period when we were developing the Ombre handloom technique. After weeks of experimenting,
we finally got to a point where the colours seamlessly blended and our efforts were
finally rewarded. The excitement and happiness we felt at that moment was unexplainable.
Sharing that with Latha and Bandula and watching the same reaction, when we first took our
shoes to them, made it so much sweeter. Their happiness to see the result of our work has
been the most gratifying feeling we have ever had as a brand. Q DO YOU HAVE ANY ADVICE FOR
SOMEONE INTERESTED IN PURSUING HANDLOOM TEXTILE WEAVING ? The only advice we can give as a
start-up brand for anyone interested is to find your purpose. A shoe is a product, whether
it is made from handloom or not. Our sneakers are special to us because they were just the
beginning of something much more significant. Handlooms in our country have been a part of
our heritage and culture for many years. At one point, we had a thriving industry with
many factories and weaving mills. But in the past few decades,the industry has been
reaching a state of inertia. We see many handloom sellers who produce an identical product
range, often with the same aesthetics. This saturates the local market. So it is exciting
to see a few inspirational local brands stepping out of the norm to create new designs and
colour combinations to uplift the craft. At Common Folk, we believe our handloom sneakers
are just a stepping stone for the industry in Sri Lanka to grow in streetwear culture and
become enticing to the younger generations. text Nuzla Rizkiya Your comment (*)

Inaugural Launch Of The Ceylon Heritage Festival Fashion Show
Sep 11 2023. The annual Ceylon Heritage Festival by the Rachel Raj Foundation and the
Ministry of Industries will have its inaugural launch with a fashion show dedicated to
artisanal traditional textile crafts on September 27 at the Galle Face Hotel in Colombo.
The event will serve as the launch pad for the new “Heritage Hands” label, a 100% Sri
Lankan-crafted clothing and accessory brand endorsed by the Industrial Development Board.
For years, Sri Lanka’s textile cottage industries have been one of the island’s best-kept
secrets. From our dumbara weavers in the hill country to our beeralu lace makers down
south and our palymrah fibre textiles from the north, nowhere in the world boasts the
unique craftsmanship and quality of these centuries-old artisanal textiles. The art of the
craft is privy to only a select few in rural Sri Lanka and has been passed down from
generation to generation in order to keep this art form alive. Unfortunately, being the
island's best-kept secret is slowly killing this indigenous craft as artisans struggle to
compete with the cheaper, lower-quality alternatives with little to no access or support
to enter new markets. Where countries like Mexico and Africa, which create unique
textiles, market their cultural crafts to the world, our traditional textiles fly under
the radar with limited global exposure. Coupled with soaring costs of living and finding
little opportunity in the industry, this generational heritage craft is on the decline and
very much at risk of disappearing altogether. Sarita Rajandran, Founder and Managing
Director of the Rachel Raj resort and swimwear brand which employs and works closely with
several artisans of the crafts for the luxury fashion label, is well aware of the
struggles these artistes face and believes that these traditional textile industries are
severely underutilised and undervalued. "One of the reasons the cottage industries are
declining is that these crafts haven't been curated to cater to the modern palate. The
global market is crazy for traditional craftsmanship in fashion, but it needs to be modern
and wearable, and because we haven't developed our craft to blend in with the times, our
artisans are missing out on a huge market opportunity." In celebration of her label's 10th
anniversary this year, Sarita founded the Rachel Raj Foundation to empower and promote
traditional textile crafts in international markets. Together with the Ministry of
Industries, under the guidance of the Minister, Hon. (Dr.) Ramesh Pathirana and the
Industrial Development Board, the Ceylon Heritage Festival was conceptualised to showcase
Sri Lanka's heritage industries of fashion, art, music, literature, and more. While the
Festival is set to be an annual encounter, the inaugural event will be marked by a Fashion
Show this year, in a conscious effort to preserve the country's resources given the
current economic crunch. The Ceylon Heritage Festival Fashion Show will showcase the role
of Sri Lanka's indigenous textile crafts in modern design palettes with the launch of the
Heritage Hands label. The label will incorporate pieces where traditional crafts, such as
dumbara weaving, beeralu lace, bamboo and palmyra fibre fabric, crochet, handloom and
batik printing will be the mainstay of the collection. While these textile crafts are
often visualised in a traditional setting, the Heritage Hands collection juxtaposes the
old with the new, showcasing how effortlessly tradition and trend can combine to bridge
the gap between heritage and contemporary fashion. The show will also feature pieces
designed by the graduates of Moratuwa University's Fashion Textile Engineering department.
Following the launch of the brand, the Heritage Hands collection will be made available
exclusively at Laksala stores islandwide. Speaking on the IDB’s endorsement and support
given to the Festival and the Heritage Hands label, the Chairman of the IDB, Dr. Saranga
Alahapperuma shared that the Board together with the Ministry are looking positively at
this show as it is the first-ever fashion show dedicated solely to the cottage industries.
“Over 20,000 skilled artisans work in this industry, but sadly, because they aren't
utilising modern marketing techniques to expand into new markets and because theyfrequently target low-end local markets, there is little industry growth and very little
interaction from the younger generations because they don't see much future potential in
their craft right now. Because of this, we want to take it on and support these artisans
by making it easier for them to access new, international markets.” “The traditional
textile crafts produce very unique designs and high-quality, sustainable material. With
the fashion show and the label, I think buyers can see the versatility of this market and
we hope to take the craft offshore and give these artisans the support they need to pitch
to foreign buyers and international shows.” The Ceylon Heritage Festival Fashion Show will
be presented to foreign buyers and the diplomatic strata as well as the public in hopes of
attracting international buyers and fostering collaborations that can further boost the
export of these industries and pave the way to enter new markets. The Festival not only
aims to contribute to the growth of Sri Lanka's economy and bring exposure to
international markets but also, and perhaps more importantly, help preserve and pass down
the art of traditional textile crafting to future generations. Tickets are priced Rs. 5000
and are inclusive of the fashion show and cocktail beverages. Tickets will be available at
Ramani Fernando Salons - Elibank Road (Tuesday-Saturday 9.30 – 5pm) and Borella ( 9.30 –
5pm Daily) and Playtrix Sports Bar Colombo City Centre (11-6pm Daily). (Pix Courtesy: RRF)
